actions-list.actionItem: The House has concluded all anticipated legislative business and has proceeded to Special Order speeches.
The House proceeded with further one minute speeches.

actions-list.header: The Speaker laid before the House a message from the President transmitting a notification stating that the national emergency with respect to hostage-taking and the wrongful detention of United States nationals abroad declared in Executive Order 14078 of July 19, 2022, is to continue in effect beyond July 19, 2025
actions-list.actionItem: referred to the Committee on Foreign Affairs and ordered to be printed (H. Doc. 119-69).

The House received a message from the Clerk. Pursuant to the permission granted in Clause 2(h) of Rule II of the Rules of the U.S. House of Representatives, the Clerk notified the House that he had received a sealed envelope from the White House on July 15, 2025, at 4:35 p.m., said to contain a message from the President on the Continuation of the National Emergency With Respect to Hostage-Taking and the Wrongful Detention of United States Nationals Abroad.

The House received a communication from The Honorable Sam Graves, Chairman, Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure. Pursuant to section 3307 of Title 40, United States Code, the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure met on July 15, 2025, to consider seven resolutions included in the General Services Administration's Capital Investment and Leasing Programs. Copies of the resolutions adopted by the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure were enclosed. Referred to the Committee on Appropriations.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of July 15.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is subject to the call of the Chair.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 380
actions-list.actionItem: 33 (Roll no. 196).

Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 1717 — "To direct the Federal Communications Commission to establish a council to make recommendations on ways to increase the security, reliability, and interoperability of communications networks, and for other purposes."

The Chair put the question on the motion to reconsider and by voice vote, announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mr. McGovern demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Mr. Scalise moved to reconsider the vote.

actions-list.header: On agreeing to the resolution Failed by recorded vote: 196

actions-list.actionItem: Considered as unfinished business. H. Res. 580 — "Providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 4016) making appropriations for the Department of Defense for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2026, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 3633) to provide for a system of regulation of the offer and sale of digital commodities by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 1919) to amend the Federal Reserve Act to prohibit the Federal reserve banks from offering certain products or services directly to an individual, to prohibit the use of central bank digital currency for monetary policy, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of the bill (S. 1582) to provide for the regulation of payment stablecoins, and for other purposes; and waiving a requirement of clause 6(a) of rule XIII with respect to consideration of certain resolutions reported from the Committee on Rules."
The House observed a moment of silence in remembrance of the victims of the recent flooding in Texas.

The Chair put the question on agreeing to the resolution and by voice vote, announced that the ayes had prevailed. Ms. Scanlon demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.

actions-list.header: On ordering the previous question Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: 211

actions-list.actionItem: The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H. Res. 580.

Considered as privileged matter. H. Res. 580 — "Providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 4016) making appropriations for the Department of Defense for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2026, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 3633) to provide for a system of regulation of the offer and sale of digital commodities by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 1919) to amend the Federal Reserve Act to prohibit the Federal reserve banks from offering certain products or services directly to an individual, to prohibit the use of central bank digital currency for monetary policy, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of the bill (S. 1582) to provide for the regulation of payment stablecoins, and for other purposes; and waiving a requirement of clause 6(a) of rule XIII with respect to consideration of certain resolutions reported from the Committee on Rules."

actions-list.header: Congressional-Executive Commission on the People's Republic of China
actions-list.actionItem: Pursuant to 22 U.S.C. 6913, and the order of the House of January 3, 2025, the Speaker appointed the following members of the House to the Congressional-Executive Commission on the People's Republic of China: Mr. Suozzi and Mr. Subramanyam.
The House resumed one minute speeches.
The House received a message from the Senate. The Senate passed S. 283 and S. 433.
The House proceeded with one minute speeches, which by direction of the Chair would be limited to 15 per side of the aisle.
The Chair designated Mr. Raskin to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.
The Speaker announced approval of the Journal.  Pursuant to clause 1, rule I, the Journal stands approved.
Today's prayer was offered by the House Chaplain, Chaplain Margaret Grun Kibben.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of July 15.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for 12:00 P.M. today.
The House proceeded with Morning-Hour Debate. At the conclusion of Morning-Hour, the House will recess until 12:00 p.m. for the start of legislative business.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Blake D. Moore to act as Speaker pro tempore for today.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
